ol.li: Understand the equivalence between a system of linear equations and a vector equation.
Learn the definition of \Span\{x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_p\}, and how to draw pictures of spans.
Recipe: solve a vector equation using augmented matrices / decide if a vector is in a span.
Pictures: an inconsistent system of equations, a consistent system of equations, spans in \R^2 and \R^3.

subsection.title: Vector Equations

statement.p: A vector equation is an equation involving a linear combination of vectors with possibly unknown coefficients.
Is \vec{ 8 16 3} a linear combination of \vec{1 2 6} and \vec{-1 -2 -1}?

note.title: A Picture of a Consistent System
note.p: We saw in the above that the system of equations is consistent. Equivalently, this means that the vector equation has a solution. Therefore, the above is a picture of a consistent system of equations. Compare this below.

bluebox.title: Recipe: Solving a vector equation
bluebox.p: In general, the vector equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_pv_p = b where v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p,\,b are vectors in \R^n and x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_p are unknown scalars, has the same solution set as the linear system with augmented matrix \amat[c]{| | ,{} , | |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_p b; | | ,{} , | |} whose columns are the v_is and the bs.

subsection.p:
Now we have (at least) two equivalent ways of thinking about systems of equations:
Augmented matrices.
Linear combinations of vectors (vector equations).
The second is more geometric in nature: it lends itself to drawing pictures.

subsection.title: Spans
subsection.p: It will be important to know what are all linear combinations of a set of vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p in \R^n. In other words, we would like to understand the set of all vectors b in \R^n such that the vector equation (in the unknowns x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_p) x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_pv_p = b has a solution (i.e. is consistent).

statement.p: Let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p be vectors in \R^n. The span of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p is the collection of all linear combinations of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p, and is denoted \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\}. In symbols: \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\}Span of vectors \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} = \bigl\{x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_pv_p \mid x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_p \text{ in }\R\bigr\} We also say that \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} is the subset spanned by or generated by the vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p.

subsection.p: The above is the first of several essential definitions that we will see in this textbook. They are essential in that they form the essence of the subject of linear algebra: learning linear algebra means (in part) learning these definitions. All of the definitions are important, but it is essential that you learn and understand the definitions marked as such.

note.title: Set Builder Notation
note.p: The notation \{x\mid\text{condition}\}Set builder notation \bigl\{x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_pv_p \mid x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_p \text{ in }\R\bigr\} reads as: the set of all things of the form x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_pv_p such that x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_p are in \R. The vertical line is such that; everything to the left of it is the set of all things of this form, and everything to the right is the condition that those things must satisfy to be in the set. Specifying a set in this way is called set builder notation.
All mathematical notation is only shorthand: any sequence of symbols must translate into a usual sentence.

note.title: Three characterizations of consistency
note.p:
Now we have three equivalent ways of making the same statement:
A vector b is in the span of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p.
The vector equation x_1v_1 + x_2v_2 + \cdots + x_pv_p = b has a solution.
The linear system with augmented matrix \amat[c]{| | ,{} , | |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_p b; | | ,{} , | |} is consistent.

subsection.p: Equivalent means that, for any given list of vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p,\,b, either all three statements are true, or all three statements are false.

paragraphs.title: Pictures of Spans
paragraphs.p: Drawing a picture of \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} is the same as drawing a picture of all linear combinations of v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p.

Pictures of spans in \R^3. The span of two noncollinear vectors is the plane containing the origin and the heads of the vectors. Note that three coplanar (but not collinear) vectors span a plane and not a 3-space, just as two collinear vectors span a line and not a plane.
